issue.title: Expose `TimeSeries` time range & zoom in the Blueprint API

labels.name: ðŸŸ¦ blueprint
labels.description: The data that defines our UI

repository.name: rerun
repository.description: Visualize streams of multimodal data. Free, fast, easy to use, and simple to integrate. Built in Rust.

issue.body:
### Related

- Part of #4818.
- Closes #8050.
- Closes #11260.

- Moving the view with a trackpad has issues, see https://github.com/emilk/egui/issues/7657 and RR-2730. But this was a pre-existing issue. Temporarily fixed by https://github.com/rerun-io/rerun/pull/11627

### What

Adds a time range and zoom lock components to the time series view blueprint. Allowing you to change the view via the python API.

- [x] The UI code for the time range component used here more or less duplicates what is used for `VisibleTimeRange`. Looks difficult to deduplicate, but maybe look into it more?

body: Looking into it a bit more, this might be the mac trackpad delaying scroll events. Which I think makes this considerably harder to fix.

I'm now working on a fix, that's slightly different from what I first had in mind.

`winit` has a `phase` value in the `MouseWheel` event, which I can use to have egui track if we're currently scrolling. What's left now is how to handle this on web.

`winit` [seems to just send the `Moved` phase on the web](https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit/blob/v0.30.12/src/platform_impl/web/event_loop/window_target.rs#L509), which we could also do. But that would mean this would still be broken on web ðŸ˜• 

<details>
<summary>Logged mouse wheel events kinetic scrolling on a mac</summary>

Notice the frame delay between events:


issue.title: Temporary fix for kinematic scrolling in views

labels.name: ðŸ˜¤ annoying
labels.description: Something in the UI / SDK is annoying to use

labels.name: ðŸŸ¦ blueprint
labels.description: The data that defines our UI

labels.name: exclude from changelog
labels.description: PRs with this won't show up in CHANGELOG.md

repository.name: rerun
repository.description: Visualize streams of multimodal data. Free, fast, easy to use, and simple to integrate. Built in Rust.

issue.body:
### Related

- Part of RR-2730

### What

When kinematic scrolling inside the time view it would add a lot of undo inflection points because of https://github.com/emilk/egui/issues/7657. This is a workaround for that.

body:
I think the way to go for this on web is having a timeout since the last time you scrolled. Not the prettiest solution though.

On my mac the largest delta I got between scroll events when doing kinematic scroll was 68 ms, so could probably be a 100ms timeout.

Seems like there is no web API for begin/end scroll events: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/wheel_event#event_properties

So yeah, some sort of timeout is probably needed.

We should have some sort of `input.is_scrolling()` helper for this

issue.title: Add `is_scrolling`/`is_smooth_scrolling` util, checking for active scroll action.

repository.name: egui
repository.description: egui: an easy-to-use immediate mode GUI in Rust that runs on both web and native

issue.body:
* Closes #7657
* [x] I have followed the instructions in the PR template

On native this uses a new "touch phase" parameter of the mouse wheel event to know if a scroll action is done.
